questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone 

 

SALTER HARRIS CLASSIFICATION 

  • The arrangement of cells of the physis is in layers or zones. 
  • These layers include the reserve, proliferative and hypertrophic zones. 
  • The reserve zone serves as the storage area for lipids, proteoglycans, and glycogen for growth and matrix production later. 
  • The proliferative zone has the highest rate of extracellular matrix production and accounts for the most abundant longitudinal growth. 
  • The hypertrophic zone has three phases: 
    • Maturation allows for preparation for calcification
    • Degenerative further prepare the matrix
    • Provisional calcification zone is where chondrocyte death occurs, allowing for calcium release. 
  • Physeal fractures most commonly occur in the zone of provisional calcification, as it is the weakest in response to shearing stress. 
  • The physis is weaker than ligaments or periosteum in children, causing injury to the growth plate before other structures. 
  • Zones of physis:

 

 

 

  • Salter and Harris described two major types of epiphyseal plates: the pressure epiphysis and the traction epiphysis. 
  • Pressure epiphyses provide longitudinal growth, at the end of long bones, are intra-articular, and bear weight. 
  • Traction epiphyses provide appositional growth, at the origin or insertion of muscles, are extra-articular, and do not bear weight. 
  • Their classification focuses on injuries at pressure epiphyses. 
  • They recognized that physeal fractures consistently occur through the same histologic plane called the zone of provisional calcification. 
  • This zone, located in the zone of hypertrophy, represents a transitional point between calcified and non-calcified extracellular matrix proteins, making it weaker than its surrounding osseous-ligamentous structures, and therefore more susceptible to injury.

 

 

  • In type I injury, there is slip of epiphysis with damage to the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting zone: It is affected in storage disorders like Gaucher’s disease. 

 

Option B. Proliferative zone: It is affected in growth hormone defects like Larsen’s syndrome. 

 

Option D. Zone of provisional calcification: It is affected in mineralization defects like rickets. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. 
  • It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. 
  • Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

choices.text: Transverse perineal muscles
Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obturator muscle

 

Explanation:

 

The obturator muscle is not cut in a mediolateral episiotomy. It is located deeper in the pelvis and is not involved in the incision made during this procedure.

 

Structures cut in a mediolateral episiotomy:

 

  • Posterior vaginal wall mucosa
  • Perineal muscles:
    • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Part of levator ani
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

 

Other options:

 

In a mediolateral episiotomy, the following structures are typically cut to facilitate childbirth:

 

Option A. Transverse perineal muscles: These include the superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles.

 

Option C. Bulbospongiosus: A muscle of the perineum that is also incised during the procedure.

 

Option D. Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves: These branches can be affected during the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a mediolateral episiotomy, various perineal structures, including the posterior vaginal wall mucosa, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin, are incised. The obturator muscle is not involved in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 649

questions.text: A patient who used to workout regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS

 

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) is the cellular death of components of bone due to impaired blood supply.
  • It affects anterolateral aspect of femoral head.
  • Etiopathogenesis: Idiopathic (most common) – called as Chandeliers disease.
  • Causes:

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Age 20-50 years with slight male preponderance (Young Male).
    • Bilateral in 50% of idiopathic cases, and 80% of steroid-induced cases.
    • Decreased range of motion especially internal rotation followed by abduction – characteristic feature
    • A characteristic sign is a tendency for hip to twist into external rotation during passive flexion - ‘Sectoral sign’ – with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed, it is grossly restricted – due to a sector of femoral head being involved in AVN.
    • X-rays Sclerosed area shows area of necrosis; Crescent sign – Crescentric defect in subchondral area.

 

 

  • MRI is the investigation of choice – Double line sign is seen.
  • T1: Reduced intensity or irregular outline of head.
  • T2: High signal intensity called as double line sign.

 

 

  • Classification system:
    • University at Pennsylvania system:
      • Mild AVN: < 15% of Femoral head involved
      • Moderate AVN: 15-30% of Femoral head involved
      • Severe AVN: >30% of Femoral head involved
         
  • Treatment:
    • Early stages: protected weight-bearing.
    • Pre-collapse stage: Core decompression to decrease intraosseous pressure in femoral head (Normal Intraosseous pressure = 10-20 mm Hg; 3-4 times in AVN). Drill holes are made in femoral head. This procedure also opens the channels for vascular ingrowths and it is also supplemented with bone grafting (Vascular or nonvascular) or electrical stimulation or bone morphogenic proteins.

 

 

  • Muscle Pedicle graft: Quadratus femoris (Meyers graft)/Tensor fascia lata graft (Joshi’s graft) can be fixed in femoral head to augment vascularity.

 

 

  • Rotational osteotomy: To get the intact part of femoral head in acetabulum weight-bearing area (anterolateral aspect of femur head) this is an extensive procedure requiring vascular repair along with it.

 

 

  • Arthritis/Collapse of femoral head: Total hip replacement one of the very commonly done procedure as most patients present at stage of arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB of hip. Initial focus is in the acetabulum. The majority of cases of hip TB presents as painful, restricted movements of the hip, and a limp. It is secondary to primary pathology in lungs, lymph nodes or any of the viscera. Disease usually starts during first three decades. Depending upon the extent of involvement, there can be deformity, shortening of the limb, swelling, pathological dislocations, and sinuses.

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum

 

 

Stage of arthritis

 

Treatment involved Girdlestone excision arthroplasty/arthrodesis/THR.

 

 

Stage I and II are treated with ATT and traction. If required, joint debridement/synovectomy can be done. Stage III, IV and V are treated with ATT and joint replacement/arthrodesis/osteotomy/excision arthroplasty.

 

Option C. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures of the femoral neck put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing ability of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. The patient will complain of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. MRI is more sensitive (100% sensitivity) and specific for diagnosis.

 

 

 

 

Garden’s classification

 

Treatment is done by closed reduction and internal fixation in age < 65 years. In age > 65 years, hemiarthroplasty is done if there is a pre-existing arthritis. If there is no pre-existing arthritis, total hip replacement is done.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Often referred to as "soft bone disease," is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by the inadequate mineralization of bone tissue. There is adult onset of bone softening and muscle weakness. This condition results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, weakening and softening bones. Symptoms are non-specific and may include low back and thigh pain, proximal muscle weakness and wasting; Myalgia and arthralgia; Muscle spasms; waddling gait; Spinal, limb, or pelvic deformities; Aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing; Increased falls; Hypocalcemic seizures or tetany. Triradiate pelvis, protrusion acetabular (acetabulum protrudes into pelvis due to bone softening. When bilateral, it is called as Otto Pelvis), pseudofracture are seen on x-ray. There is waddling gait due to muscular weakness.

 

 

A. Triradiate pelvis; B. Protrusio acetabuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip.
  • Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MSH2

 

MSH2 stands for "MutS homolog 2." The gene is located on chromosome 2 and is not directly involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Instead, MSH2 is a key component of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) pathway. MMR is responsible for correcting errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches and small insertions or deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BRCA1: BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Option C. KU70: KU70, along with KU80, forms the Ku heterodimer (Ku70/Ku80), which is a crucial component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. NHEJ is a major mechanism for repairing double-strand DNA breaks, especially in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option D. ATM: The ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia mutated) gene codes for a protein kinase that plays a central role in the cellular response to double-strand DNA breaks. It activates a signaling cascade that leads to DNA repair and cell cycle control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation, you notice the different color-coded waste bins meticulously arranged by the nursing staff as per the hospital's waste management protocol. If you were to guide a new intern about the appropriate disposal of items, which item among the following would you instruct them to discard in the black bin? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Glove paper cover

 

  • The paper cover for gloves constitutes regular solid waste, which should be placed in the designated black bin.
  • All types of non-infectious general refuse, including food waste, paper waste, and mineral water bottles, ought to be deposited in the black bins.
  • Bedsheets and linens that are soiled and contaminated with blood or bodily fluids should be appropriately disposed of in the yellow bin.
  • Plastic materials that are recyclable, such as gloves and contaminated gloves, should be placed in the red bins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soiled linen bedsheet: Should be disposed of in the yellow bin for contaminated waste.

 

Option C. Gloves: Should be placed in the red bin for recyclable materials.

 

Option D. Contaminated gloves: Also go in the red bin for medical waste.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-infectious general refuse, such as glove paper covers, should be discarded in the black bin.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen. Pompe's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is not the correct enzyme. Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with von Gierke's disease, a glycogen storage disorder. It primarily affects the liver and kidney.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: Muscle phosphorylase is associated with McArdle's disease, a glycogen storage disorder affecting skeletal muscles. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui's disease, another glycogen storage disorder. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

choices.text: 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts

questions.text: Which of the following patients would be classified as having primary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts

 

  • Primary amenorrhea is defined as:
    • No menstruation by age 13 in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics.
    • No menstruation by age 15 in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • In this context:
    • Option A: An 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts would not be classified as having primary amenorrhea since she is not yet 13.
    • Option B: A 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts meets the criteria for primary amenorrhea because she is older than 13 and has no secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 1 breasts).
    • Option C: A 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.
    • Option D: A 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts: The girl is too young to be classified as having primary amenorrhea.

 

Option C. 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Option D. 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by age 13 without secondary sexual characteristics or by age 15 with secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Ref: ACOG Committee opinion menstruation in girls and adolescents (2015), Speroff’s gynecologic endocrinology 7th edition pg401, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 450

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d

 

  1. Eonism: a. Sexual gratification by cross-dressing. This term is used to describe individuals who derive sexual pleasure from dressing in clothes traditionally worn by the opposite gender.
  2. Frotteurism: b. The act of rubbing one's genitals against a non-consenting person, usually in a crowded place, such as public transport. It is considered a paraphilic disorder.
  3. Necrophilia: c. Sexual stimulation by corpses. This is a rare and extreme paraphilia where individuals are sexually aroused by deceased bodies.
  4. Algolagnia: d. Sexual gratification in inflicting or suffering pain. This can involve either sadism (inflicting pain) or masochism (receiving pain) as part of sexual activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism is sexual gratification by cross-dressing, frotteurism involves rubbing genitals against a non-consenting person, necrophilia is sexual stimulation by corpses, and algolagnia involves sexual gratification from inflicting or suffering pain.

choices.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ secretion, active CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: The second phase of saliva secretion involves: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

 

First, sodium ions are actively reabsorbed from all the salivary ducts and potassium ions are actively secreted in exchange for the sodium. Excess sodium reabsorption over potassium secretion, creates electrical negativity of about -70 millivolts in the salivary ducts; this in turn causes chloride ions to be reabsorbed passively. Therefore, the chloride ion concentration in the salivary fluid falls to a very low level, matching the ductal decrease in sodium ion concentration.

 

Active Na+ reabsorption

 

(The ductal cells actively transport sodium ions (Na+) from the saliva into the interstitial fluid surrounding the ducts. This reabsorption of sodium ions helps in concentrating the saliva). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive Cl- reabsorption

(As sodium ions are reabsorbed, chloride ions (Cl-) passively follow along due to electrical charge balance. This results in the reabsorption of chloride ions from the saliva into the interstitial fluid). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Active K+ secretion

(The ductal cells actively secrete potassium ions (K+) into the saliva. This secretion helps in maintaining the concentration of potassium ions within the saliva). Conc.  30 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive secretion of HCO3-

(Hydrogen carbonate ions (HCO3-) are passively secreted from the ductal cells into the saliva. This helps in maintaining the alkaline nature of saliva, which aids in buffering acidic substances and maintaining oral pH). Conc. 50 to 70 mEq/L,

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. While Na+ and Cl- processes are correct, K+ secretion is active, not passive.

 

Option B. Passive Na+ reabsorption, active Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption and Cl- reabsorption roles are reversed, and K+ secretion is active.

 

Option C. Passive Na+ secretion, active Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption should be active, not passive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The second phase of saliva secretion involves active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, and passive secretion of HCO3-, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and pH in saliva.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: Glycosylated Hb (Hb-A1c) is best detected by: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ion exchange

 

Ion exchange chromatography is a highly effective method for detecting glycosylated hemoglobin (Hb-A1c). This technique separates hemoglobin molecules based on their net charge differences. Hb-A1c, which is glycated hemoglobin, has a different net charge compared to non-glycated hemoglobin. As a result, it can be quantified accurately using ion exchange chromatography. This method is widely accepted and used in clinical laboratories for monitoring long-term blood sugar control in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography: Affinity chromatography relies on the specific binding between a molecule of interest and a ligand immobilized on a chromatography column. While affinity chromatography can be used for various biomolecular separations, it is not the method of choice for detecting Hb-A1c. The affinity column would need to have a specific ligand that binds selectively to Hb-A1c, and this approach is less commonly employed compared to ion exchange chromatography for this purpose.

 

Option C. Isoelectric focussing: Isoelectric focussing is a technique that separates proteins based on their isoelectric points (pI), which is the pH at which a protein carries no net electrical charge. While this method can separate different hemoglobin variants based on their pI values, it may not be as precise as ion exchange chromatography for quantifying Hb-A1c specifically, as it relies on charge differences related to pI rather than glycation.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis: Electrophoresis is a general technique for separating molecules based on their charge and size differences in an electric field. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can separate different hemoglobin variants, including Hb-A1c, based on their charge differences. However, it may not provide the same level of specificity and accuracy as ion exchange chromatography when it comes to quantifying Hb-A1c.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPLC based methods are gold standards for measurement of Hb-A1c. These methods further include ion exchange and affinity chromatography-based methods of which Ion exchange method is considered as the best and widely used method followed by affinity chromatography and enzymatic and immunological methods.

 

Ref- https://www.japi.org/v264/hba1c-result-does-it-depend-upon-the-testing-methods-

questions.text: A patient is not able to see the lateral fields. He was having a mild headache for a few weeks and now presented to the clinic. Visual field examination shows the following finding. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

 

The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours.

 

Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipital lobe: Lesions here typically cause congruent homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field is lost in both eyes, not bitemporal defects.

 

Option C. Optic tract: Lesions in the optic tract cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Optic radiation: Lesions here also cause homonymous hemianopia, but depending on the location, they might lead to variations like a superior or inferior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

questions.text: Identify the crystal in a patient with urinary pH of 8.7: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple Phosphate

 

Normally, urinary pH typically ranges from 4.4 to 6.5, which is acidic.

 

Here, an alkaline urinary pH of 8.7 promotes the formation of certain types of crystals, particularly triple phosphate (struvite) and calcium phosphate crystals. The image provided shows typical "coffin-lid" shaped crystals, which are characteristic of triple phosphate (magnesium ammonium phosphate) or struvite crystals.

 

Triple Phosphate crystals are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Ureaplasma urealyticum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium Oxalate : These crystals typically form in acidic urine and have different shapes, such as envelope or dumbbell shapes.

 

Option C. Cystine : These crystals also form in acidic urine and have a distinctive hexagonal shape.

 

Option D. Uric Acid : These crystals form in acidic urine and appear as rhomboid or rosette shapes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple phosphate (struvite) crystals are associated with alkaline urine and have a "coffin-lid" appearance. They are commonly seen in patients with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive organisms.

questions.text: The radiograph presented below has been taken to enhance the evaluation of the frontal sinus. What is the widely used term for this particular perspective?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caldwell view

 

  • The above X ray shows the Caldwell view in which the frontal sinus is best seen.
  • Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Frontal sinuses (Best Visualization).
    2. Ethmoid sinuses.
    3. Maxillary sinuses.
    4. Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone.
    5. Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea.
    6. Superior orbital fissure.
    7. Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view: Primarily used for examining the maxillary sinuses and can also show the frontal sinuses but with less clarity than the Caldwell view.

 

Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard term in radiographic terminology.

 

Option D. Towne's view: Used to visualize the occipital bone and foramen magnum, not typically used for sinus examination.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass
Useful in young females with dense breast
Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast

questions.text: Which of the following isn't considered a benefit of USG compared to Mammography?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

 

Ultrasound has no role in detecting non-palpable breast cancers.

 

Ultrasound is particularly useful in young women with dense breasts in whom mammograms are difficult to interpret, and in distinguishing cysts from solid lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Useful in young females with dense breast: Ultrasound is indeed beneficial in young women with dense breast tissue where mammograms can be harder to interpret due to the denseness of the tissue obscuring the view of potential abnormalities.

 

Option C. Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast: Ultrasound is particularly effective in distinguishing between solid and cystic lesions within the breast. This ability is crucial for determining the nature of a breast mass and guiding further diagnostic and treatment actions.

 

Option D. Guided biopsy can be done: Ultrasound-guided biopsy is a well-established procedure that uses ultrasound imaging to guide the needle to the precise location of the abnormal tissue in the breast for sampling. This is particularly useful for targeting lesions that are visible on ultrasound but not palpable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound should not be considered a standalone screening tool for non-palpable breast masses or those not detected by mammography. However, it is invaluable in specific scenarios such as evaluating women with dense breasts, distinguishing between cystic and solid breast lesions, and facilitating guided biopsies.

choices.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains
Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation:

 

Option C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation: This is the correct explanation. 2,3 BPG binds to a specific site in hemoglobin's central cavity, which is surrounded by histidine and lysine residues. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, favoring the release of oxygen molecules from hemoglobin into the surrounding tissues. The formation of salt bridges as a result of this binding contributes to the release of oxygen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not directly affect ATP production or break links between globin chains.

 

Option B. It increases ATP production: This statement is not correct. 2,3 BPG is not involved in ATP production.

 

Option D. Inhibits Taut structure formation: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not inhibit the formation of the Taut structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production
  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) plays a crucial role in regulating oxygen delivery by binding to deoxyhemoglobin and stabilizing the T (taut) state, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thereby promoting oxygen unloading to tissues.

 

 

  • When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequence? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Crowning
  2. Engagement
  3. Restitution
  4. External rotation
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B, A, C, D

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence of cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor is a series of positions and motions that the fetus goes through as it navigates through the birth canal. These movements are:

 

  1. Engagement: This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim.
  2. Descent: The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet.
  3. Flexion: The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal.
  4. Internal Rotation: The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis.
  5. Crowning: The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back.
  6. Extension: The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis.
  7. Restitution: The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis.
  8. External Rotation: The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head.
  9. Expulsion of the rest of the body: The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. B, A, D, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before restitution.

 

Option C. B, C, A, D: This sequence incorrectly places restitution before crowning.

 

Option D. B, D, A, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before crowning and restitution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor occur in the following sequence: engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension (preceded by crowning), restitution, external rotation, and expulsion of the rest of the body.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 145

questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule, where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament.
  • Lesions of the glenoid labrum are most commonly the result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion. A Hill-Sachs lesion is an osseous defect or "dent" of the postero-supero-lateral humeral head that occurs in association with anterior instability or dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. It is often associated with a Bankart lesion of the glenoid. This lesion is caused by an anterior shoulder dislocation which causes a humeral head impression fracture. The posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the anterior glenoid in the dislocated position, causing shoulder instability. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum is called Bankart’s lesion, which is caused due to traumatic anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

choices.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral mRNA
Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.text: SARS-Cov-2 can be detected by all except? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Southern blotting

 

Southern Blotting: This technique is used for the detection of specific DNA sequences in DNA samples. This is not applicable for detecting SARS-CoV-2 because the virus is RNA-based and there is not enough DNA in the collected samples to obtain a pattern on gel electrophoresis. RNA viruses require different techniques such as RT-PCR for detection.

 

Other Options

 

Tests for SARS CoV2

 

  • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR):

  • Method: This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.

  • Explanation: It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.

  • Rapid Antigen Test:

  • Method: This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.

  • Explanation: It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.

  • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay):

  • Method: This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.

  • Explanation: It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.

 

Educational Objective

 

Southern blotting is not a suitable method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 as it is designed to detect DNA, while SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus and requires RNA-specific detection techniques.

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Explanation:

 

Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.

 

 

C banding: stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.

 

Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.

 

Note –  Q banding: uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

 

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • HBsAg - NR,
  • Anti HBs - NR,
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR,
  • Anti HBc total - positive,
  • HBeAg - NR,
  • Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's serological markers indicate the following:

 

  • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.

 

  • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.

 

  • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.

 

  • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.

 

  • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.

 

Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

choices.text: TPE removes the von Willebrand factor
TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is caused by a deficiency of ADAMTS13, usually due to autoantibodies. Total plasma exchange (TPE) removes these autoantibodies, thereby increasing ADAMTS13 protease activity and preventing the accumulation of large von Willebrand factor multimers. This results in platelet trapping. Classic clinical picture includes:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • End-organ damage (neurological injury)
  • Fever

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. TPE removes the von Willebrand factor: Incorrect; the goal is to remove autoantibodies.
 

Option B. TPE removes the antiplatelet antibodies: Incorrect; TTP involves anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies.
 

Option C. TPE replenishes the coagulation factors: Incorrect; TTP is not primarily a coagulation factor deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPE in TTP primarily removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies, increasing ADAMTS13 activity and reducing microthrombi formation.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Allergic rhinitis is a condition characterized by symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose, and itchy eyes. These symptoms can lead to several physical signs due to chronic inflammation and repetitive actions like rubbing the nose and eyes. However we do not see Otto Veraguth folds in Allergic Rhinitis.

 Also known as Veraguth folds, these are small creases on the upper eyelid and are not related to allergic rhinitis. They are typically associated with individuals suffering from depression, not allergic conditions.

Other Options:

Option A. Allergic Shiners: Commonly seen in allergic rhinitis due to venous congestion under the eyes.

Option B. Allergic Salute: A habitual action in allergic rhinitis leading to a nasal crease.

Option D. Dennis Morgan Lines: Found in chronic allergic conditions due to persistent inflammation and edema, including allergic rhinitis.

Educational Objective: 

Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in an inner segment of the photoreceptor? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Disc 

 

Disc membranes are specifically located in the outer segment of the photoreceptor, not the inner segment. The inner segment contains most cellular organelles, including:

 

  • Mitochondria
  • Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
  • Golgi apparatus
  • Nucleus

 

The outer segment is characterized by the presence of disc membranes, which are crucial for phototransduction. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5

 

The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

 

 

  • Color: body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate: 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

choices.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient

 

The glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) is directly proportional to GFR according to the formula. Therefore, a decrease in Kf will lead to a decrease in GFR. The filtration coefficient represents the product of the hydraulic permeability and surface area available for filtration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure will increase GFR by increasing the net filtration pressure gradient.

 

Option B. Increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. An increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure increases GFR by promoting filtration.

 

Option D. Decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure increases GFR by reducing the opposition to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and GFR are directly proportional, meaning a decrease in Kf causes a decrease in GFR.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vulval cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma.
  • Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval hematoma: Vulval hematomas may occur due to direct trauma or accidental injuries. They present as a localized collection of blood within the vulvar tissues, leading to swelling and bruising, but they do not typically form irregular fungating lesions.

 

Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

They appear as multiple, small, cauliflower-like growths and are not typically large, irregular, or fungating.

 

Option D. Bartholin cyst: A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland gets blocked due to infection, resulting in a buildup of glandular secretions.

 

It presents as a swelling on one side of the vaginal opening, but it is typically smooth and round, not irregular and fungating.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulvar cancer often presents as an irregular, fungating lesion on the vulva.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 337,338

choices.text: Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA)
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)
Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea, and tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: pH: 7.34, Sodium: 135 mmol/L, Potassium: 5 mmol/L, Bicarbonate: 12 mmol/L, Chloride: 92 mmol/L, RBS: 450 mg/dL. Given these laboratory findings, which of the following statements best describes the patient's acid-base status? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)

 

The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a condition commonly seen in diabetes patients with high blood sugar levels (RBS: 450 mg/dL). The symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are characteristic of DKA.

 

The laboratory values indicate a metabolic acidosis:

 

  • pH of 7.34: Slightly acidic, indicating acidosis.
  • Bicarbonate of 12 mmol/L: Low, consistent with metabolic acidosis.
  • Chloride of 92 mmol/L: Lower than normal.

 

To determine the type of metabolic acidosis, we calculate the anion gap:

 

 

An anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L indicates a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). In this case, the anion gap is 31, confirming HAGMA. 

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis is typically associated with conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, renal failure, and ingestion of toxins.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA): This occurs when the anion gap is normal (less than 12 mmol/L). Conditions that cause NAGMA include diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis. This does not match the patient's high anion gap.

 

Option C. Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis: This condition involves an elevated pH with high bicarbonate levels. The patient’s pH is acidic, not alkalotic, and bicarbonate is low.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Characterized by a primary increase in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels leading to a low pH. The patient’s primary disturbance is metabolic, not respiratory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by an anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L, indicating an accumulation of unmeasured anions. This condition is often seen in diabetic ketoacidosis, which presents with elevated blood glucose levels and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lethargy

 

Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration. In the context of dehydration, it is important to differentiate between signs that indicate mild to moderate (some) dehydration and those that suggest severe dehydration. Lethargy indicates a more serious state of fluid loss that affects the child's overall responsiveness and energy levels, which is not characteristic of mild or moderate dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: This sign can occur in both some and severe dehydration. When the skin, typically on the abdomen or arm, is pinched and it returns to its original position slowly, it indicates decreased skin turgor, a common sign of dehydration.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: Sunken eyes can be a symptom of both some and severe dehydration. It is a visible sign that reflects reduced fluid in the body, causing the eyes to appear sunken.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because one of the choices (lethargy) is not a sign of some dehydration but rather severe dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:


Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

choices.text: 1 & 3; a, c, d
2 & 4; b, c, e
1 & 3; a, d
2 & 4; b, e

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

Clinical findings

 

a. Pulsus bisferiens

b. Pulsus alternans

c. Ejection systolic murmur

d. Murmur increases on standing

e. Murmur decreases on standing

 

Management

 

1. Beta-blockers are given

2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated

3. ICD is indicated

4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

The echocardiography findings and symptoms are indicative of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, due to the thickening of the heart muscle, there is a dynamic obstruction to blood flow, often worsening with decreased preload, such as when standing.

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a) is commonly observed in conditions like HCM, where there are two distinct peaks in arterial pulse per cardiac cycle due to the dynamic obstruction.
  • Ejection systolic murmur (c) is typical in HCM and is due to the obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • Murmur increases on standing (d) in HCM due to increased obstruction with reduced venous return.

 

Regarding management:

 

  • Beta-blockers (1) are typically used in HCM to manage symptoms and reduce heart rate, thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand and the degree of obstruction.
  • ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) (3) is recommended in patients with HCM who are at high risk of sudden cardiac death.

ICD indicated for all patients with ≥1 risk factor for SCD or HCM-AF score >6%

 

MAVACAMTEN is recently approved drug which modulates b-myosin heavy chain (↓Bridging & Inotropy) & reduces the need for ablation by 80% in long term

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This is incorrect as it suggests that beta-blockers are contraindicated and includes "murmur decreases on standing," which is not characteristic of HCM. Pulsus alternans (b), indicative of severe heart failure, is not typical in HCM without heart failure.

 

Option C. It misses the key management and diagnostic features by excluding the ejection systolic murmur, which is a significant finding in HCM.

 

Option D. This incorrectly includes beta-blockers as contraindicated and excludes the key symptom of an ejection systolic murmur. It also incorrectly suggests that ICD is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Points:

 

  • All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: Open cardiac massage is what kind of wound? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contaminated

 

  • In surgical practice, wounds are categorized based on their potential contamination during the procedure, which plays a crucial role in determining the risk of infection and guiding the prophylactic antibiotic therapy. Here’s an explanation of each category in the context of an open cardiac massage:

 

This category includes open, fresh, accidental wounds and operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Contaminated wounds also include incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered. Open cardiac massage often involves emergency entry into the chest, which may not always comply with optimal sterile conditions, especially in traumatic or urgent contexts, thus falling into this category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clean: These are wounds where no inflammation is encountered, and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Clean wounds are primarily closed and do not involve placement of a drain. The risk of infection is typically the lowest in clean wounds.

 

Option C. Dirty: These wounds involve the presence of pus or perforated viscera. This kind of wound shows evidence of a bacterial infection or major contamination prior to surgery. Dirty wounds are at high risk of developing postoperative infections.

 

Option D. Clean Contaminated: These wounds involve operations on the alimentary, respiratory, genital, or urinary tracts under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Typically, these procedures involve some minor breaks in sterile technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open cardiac massage is categorized as a Contaminated wound due to the nature of emergency procedures that may involve rapid and less controlled entry into the chest cavity, leading to a higher risk of infection compared to clean surgeries. This classification underscores the importance of using appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis and stringent postoperative care to manage and minimize the risk of infection

questions.text: A baby is brought to OPD for 10-week DPT vaccination appointment. He previously experienced a fever exceeding 40°C and had an inconsolable cry at 6 weeks old after receiving a vaccination. What would be the recommended course of action moving forward? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give DT vaccine

 

The child experienced a hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode or severe reaction (fever >40°C and persistent inconsolable crying) after the previous DPT dose. These are precautionary (not absolute contraindications) for pertussis-containing vaccines like DPT, but they warrant switching to a less reactogenic formulation.

 

DT (Diphtheria + Tetanus) vaccine is recommended in such cases, as it omits the pertussis component, which is most often responsible for such adverse events.

 

This allows continuation of diphtheria and tetanus protection while avoiding further adverse events from the pertussis component.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoid DPT vaccination: Incorrect. DPT is contraindicated, but not all vaccinations should be avoided. The child should still receive protection against diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. Give DPT vaccine: Incorrect. Given the prior adverse reaction, repeating DPT may risk more serious reactions. It’s prudent to avoid the pertussis component.

 

Option D. Defer by 4 weeks: Incorrect. There's no benefit in deferring the dose. The issue is not timing but the component that caused the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe reactions (such as high fever >40.5°C, persistent inconsolable crying >3 hours, or hypotonic-hyporesponsive episodes) after a previous DPT dose are indications to withhold the pertussis component in future doses. The child should receive the DT vaccine instead.

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

 

Methanol intoxication leads to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap & high osmolal gap. Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid, which is a strong acid. The accumulation of formic acid in the bloodstream results in an increase in hydrogen ion concentration, leading to acidosis. The high anion gap indicates that there are unmeasured anions (such as formate) contributing to the acidosis. In addition to causing a high anion gap, methanol intoxication also leads to a high osmolal gap, which is another diagnostic clue in cases of toxic alcohol ingestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication does not cause alkalosis. Instead, it causes acidosis due to the production of formic acid.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because the acidosis caused by methanol intoxication is characterized by a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formate, a byproduct of methanol metabolism.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication leads to acidosis, not alkalosis, and the anion gap is elevated, not normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

 

Explanation:

 

This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.

 

Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.2 Hz: This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option B. 2 Hz: This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. 20 Hz: This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.

 

 

PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1359

questions.text: Which pathogen causes attachment-effacement lesion in the intestinal mucosa? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli


Attaching-and-effacing is the “hallmark” of the EPEC infections, a lesion that is characterized by the intimate attachment of the bacteria to the host epithelial cell membrane and the effacement of the microvilli. This mechanism is a hallmark of EPEC infections, leading to copious watery diarrhea, especially in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC): Incorrect: ETEC causes watery diarrhea through the production of enterotoxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) or cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, leading to fluid and electrolyte loss. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option C. Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC): Incorrect: EIEC invades and destroys epithelial cells lining the colon, leading to fever, cramping, watery diarrhea, and dysentery with scant, bloody stools. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option D. Diffusely adherent Escherichia coli (DAEC): Incorrect: DAEC is known for its diffuse adherence pattern to epithelial cells, causing persistent diarrhea in children. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What sign on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery in a patient who was conservatively managed in the ICU after grade 3 splenic trauma?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumoperitoneum

 

The presence of pneumoperitoneum on imaging would indicate a need for laparotomy as it suggests visceral perforation, which can lead to secondary peritonitis. Conservative management is usually recommended for splenic trauma, and surgical management is reserved for cases of hemodynamic instability or failure to respond to conservative management. Splenic angiography and embolization are also used for non-surgical management. The severity of splenic injury is graded by the AST spleen injury scale, and abdominal CT with intravenous contrast is the preferred investigation. A drop of 1g% of hemoglobin may be a physiological finding, and would not warrant a surgery.

 

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture can be managed with a urinary catheter, while distended gall bladder is a normal finding if patient has been nil per oral.

 

Grades of splenic trauma based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) spleen injury scale:

 

 

Pneumoperitoneum, the presence of air in the abdominal cavity, is a concerning sign and typically indicates a perforation of the gastrointestinal tract or another abdominal organ. In a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma, the development of pneumoperitoneum suggests a concomitant hollow viscous perforation and would likely necessitate surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoglobin falls from 11g% to 10g%: A drop in hemoglobin levels can be indicative of ongoing bleeding but may not be an immediate indication for surgery. It would typically be monitored closely, and the need for surgery would depend on the rate of decline and the overall clinical condition of the patient. Typically, a decline by >2g% Hb is suggestive of active bleed and warrants further management.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: While extraperitoneal bladder rupture is a serious condition, it is not directly related to splenic trauma. Its management involves keeping a per urethral Foleys and allowing the rupture to heal.

 

Option D. Distended Gall bladder: This is a normal physiological finding and does not mandate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum is the most concerning sign in a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma and would indicate a need for surgery, as it suggests a perforation.

questions.text: A newborn presents with umbilical cord stump bleeding and a history of recurrent bleeding episodes. Laboratory results reveal normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, but a positive clot solubility test. What coagulation factor deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XIII

 

Factor XIII is essential for stabilizing fibrin clots by cross-linking fibrin monomers. A deficiency in Factor XIII leads to an unstable clot that dissolves easily, causing excessive bleeding despite normal routine coagulation tests such as PT (Prothrombin Time) and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time).

 

  • Clinical presentation:
    • Umbilical stump bleeding is a hallmark feature of Factor XIII deficiency, occurring shortly after birth.
    •  Recurrent bleeding episodes, including delayed hemorrhage after trauma or surgery.
    •  Intracranial hemorrhage can occur even without trauma.
    • Poor wound healing due to defective clot stabilization.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, as Factor XIII operates in the final step of clot formation and does not affect routine coagulation screening tests.
    • Positive clot solubility test: Clots dissolve in 5M urea or acetic acid within 24 hours due to the lack of cross-linking fibrin.

 

Thus, the positive clot solubility test in this patient strongly indicates Factor XIII deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII (Incorrect)

 

  • Hageman factor deficiency typically doesn't cause clinical bleeding
  • Would show prolonged aPTT on testing
  • Not associated with umbilical stump bleeding

 

Option B. Factor XI (Incorrect)

 

  • Would show prolonged aPTT
  • Not characteristically associated with umbilical cord bleeding
  • Clinical bleeding is usually mild and post-traumatic

 

Option C. Factor VIII (Incorrect)

 

  • Hemophilia A would show prolonged aPTT
  • While it causes bleeding, umbilical stump bleeding is not a characteristic presentation
  • Would not have a positive clot solubility test

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XIII deficiency presents with umbilical cord bleeding and shows normal PT, aPTT, and platelet count but positive clot solubility test due to unstable clot formation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer reports symptoms of fever, body pain, and a cough. A physical examination reveals a black lesion as depicted in the accompanying image. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of IgM antibodies indicative of Scrub Typhus infection. What treatment approach would be most advisable in this case? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Doxycycline alone

 

Explanation:

 

  • This black lesion is Eschar and this is the acute case of Scrub Typhus.
  • Causative organism - Rickettsia tsutsugamushi; Vector - Mite
  • The preferred approach depends on the severity of the condition and individual patient considerations.

 

Option A. Doxycycline Alone:

 

  1. Use: This is the first-line treatment for Scrub Typhus.
  2. Mechanism: Doxycycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria, effectively controlling the infection.
  3. Why Prefer: It's highly effective and typically well-tolerated, making it suitable for most cases unless contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Doxycycline + Azithromycin: Used when there is co-infection with other pathogens that azithromycin can cover or when doxycycline alone isn't adequately effective.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline: This combination might be used in more severe cases or when the patient has complications that might benefit from a broader antibiotic coverage.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone Alone: While effective against many types of bacteria, it's not the targeted treatment for Scrub Typhus and generally not recommended unless other options are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Doxycycline alone is usually sufficient and most advisable for uncomplicated Scrub Typhus. 
  • Combination therapies may be considered in specific clinical scenarios where co-infections or severe presentations are evident.

questions.text: Which of the following drug should not be prescribed in a patient with G6PD deficiency due to risk of development of hemolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Primaquine

 

  • G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP) that regulates NADPH levels in the cell. NADPH is required for the conversion of oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione, which is required to protect the cell from oxidative damage.
  • When drugs like Primaquine are administered in a patient with G6PD deficiency, it causes free radical formation, leading to oxidative stress. This results in intravascular hemolysis.
  • Therefore, Primaquine is contraindicated in G6PD deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: Chloroquine is also an antimalarial drug but does not generally cause oxidative stress to the extent that primaquine does. It is less likely to cause hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

 

Option C. Penicillin: Penicillin is an antibiotic that is not typically associated with causing oxidative stress or hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: Tetracycline is an antibiotic that is also not associated with causing hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs contraindicated in G6PD deficiency are –

 

  • Primaquine (Tafenoquine)
  • Dapsone
  • Sulfonamides (including cotrimoxazole)
  • Nitrofurantoin

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms. This condition arises from a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex in phagocytes, which is crucial for the production of reactive oxygen species used to kill ingested pathogens.

 

Key points about CGD:

 

  • Pathophysiology: In CGD, phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils and macrophages) are unable to produce reactive oxygen species due to a defective NADPH oxidase enzyme. This impairs the killing of certain bacteria and fungi.
  • Catalase-positive organisms: These organisms can neutralize hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a reactive oxygen species that the host cells might produce. Catalase-positive bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Aspergillus species, Nocardia, and Pseudomonas.
  • Recurrent Infections: Patients with CGD frequently suffer from recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms due to their inability to effectively kill these pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyper IgM syndrome: This immunodeficiency disorder is characterized by elevated levels of IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins due to defects in class-switch recombination. Patients are more prone to infections but not specifically with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome): Patients with Job syndrome have elevated levels of IgE and suffer from recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, pneumonia, and other infections. However, their susceptibility is not specifically related to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defects in lysosomal trafficking, leading to impaired phagocytosis and recurrent bacterial infections. While patients are prone to infections, their susceptibility is not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme in phagocytes.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Anaplasma phagocytophilum

questions.text: The inclusion body Rickettsial morula is found in neutrophils during infection caused by? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplasma phagocytophilum

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum is a bacterium known to cause the disease tick-borne fever (TBF) in domestic ruminants in Ixodes ricinus-infested areas in northern Europe. This organism infects granulocytes, particularly neutrophils, leading to the formation of characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies known as morulae.

 

During an infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum, light microscopy of blood smears taken in the initial fever period can often suffice for diagnosis. When these blood smears are stained with May-Grünwald Giemsa, the organisms appear as blue cytoplasmic inclusions within the neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: This bacterium causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which does not typically involve the formation of morulae in neutrophils. Instead, it causes endothelial cell infection leading to vasculitis.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: The causative agent of Mediterranean spotted fever, also does not typically form morulae in neutrophils. Like R. rickettsii, it primarily infects endothelial cells.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: This bacterium causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) and forms morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils. This distinguishes it from Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which targets neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes the formation of Rickettsial morulae in neutrophils, whereas Ehrlichia chaffeensis forms morulae in monocytes.

 

Mnemonic "GAME": Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis.

choices.text: Increased formation of Heinz body
Males and females can be affected
Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about a patient with G6PD deficiency?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects the red blood cells' ability to handle oxidative stress.

 

This is incorrect. G6PD deficiency actually increases oxidative stress inside red blood cells because the reduced NADPH levels lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione. This makes the cells more susceptible to oxidative damage.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increased formation of Heinz body: Correct because this is a hallmark of G6PD deficiency due to oxidative damage to hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Males and females can be affected: Correct; while males are more commonly affected, females can also be affected due to the X-linked inheritance pattern.

 

Option C. Reduced NADPH: Correct because this is a direct consequence of G6PD deficiency as the enzyme is essential for NADPH production in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency increases oxidative stress in red blood cells, leading to hemolysis and formation of Heinz bodies. It affects both males and females, though more commonly males.

questions.text: The patient visiting the outpatient department exhibits skin manifestations linked to a disease that includes Raynaud’s phenomenon. What is this skin manifestation shown below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salt and pepper pigmentation.

 

  • The presented clinical scenario indicates systemic sclerosis, a complex autoimmune condition of uncertain origin with diverse clinical manifestations.
  • It leads to considerable disability and mortality, affecting nearly all organs.
  • The defining feature of systemic sclerosis is scleroderma, characterized by thickened and indurated skin.

 

Systemic sclerosis

 

It also presents with typical skin manifestations of Raynaud phenomenon, which include the characteristic white discoloration of the fingers due to vasospasm and bluish discoloration of the fingertips as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The skin has a salt-and-pepper appearance when there is a loss of pigmentation, which is most noticeable on the upper back (as given in the question), chest, and scalp.
  • Sclerodactyly and sclerosis extending proximal to the metacarpophalangeal joints with or without contractures.

 

 

  • Loss of fingertip pulp
  • Vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences
  • Puffy fingers in early disease
  • Severe flexion contractures
  • Expressionless facies, mat-like telangiectasias, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and a beak-like nose can be seen as shown in the image below

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Poikiloderma is a skin disorder characterized by (ATP)

 

  • Atrophy
  • Telangiectasias
  • Pigment abnormalities Hypo and hyper

 

 

It is seen in ionizing radiation-damaged skin and Dermatomyositis.

 

Option C: Sometimes the color of the hair can change to white in the amelanotic lesions of vitiligo. It is known as leukotrichia.

 

Option D: Sharply demarcated depigmented macules are a hallmark of vitiligo. It results from the loss of melanocytes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Salt and Pepper pigmentation' is a cutaneous manifestation often seen in systemic sclerosis, a condition which also commonly presents with Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 56 page no 56.4

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 2779

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? (NICET Nov 2020)
