questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exosome

 

Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by Exosome.

 

Exosomes are extracellular vesicles generated by all cells and they carry nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, and metabolites. They are mediators of near and long-distance intercellular communication in health and disease and affect various aspects of cell biology. These vesicles are enclosed by a lipid bilayer. They are heterogeneous in size (30-2000 m diameter).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: Lysosomes are organelles involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, cellular signaling, and energy metabolism. They do not play a direct role in intercellular communication.

 

Option B. Peroxisome: Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism and the detoxification of harmful substances. They are not involved in intercellular communication.

 

Option D. Genome: The genome refers to the complete set of genetic material within an organism. It is not a structure involved in intercellular communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

choices.text: Half-life doubles and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
Half-life and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life and plasma concentration doubles

questions.text: What would happen to the half-life and plasma concentration of a drug which follows first-order kinetics, if the dose is doubled? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
 

In case of drugs following 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated in a given time. Therefore, the half-life of the drug remains constant and the Clearance also remains constant.

 

Key points regarding first-order kinetics:

 

  • Half-life remains constant: The half-life of the drug does not change with the dose. It remains constant because the fraction of the drug eliminated per unit time is constant.
  • Clearance remains constant: The clearance, which is the volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed per unit time, remains constant.
  • Plasma concentration: When the dose is doubled, the plasma concentration of the drug also doubles because the rate of elimination is proportional to the concentration of the drug in the plasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For drugs following first-order kinetics, The rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional its plasma concentration. So, when the dose is doubled for a drug following first order kinetics, the plasma concentration is also doubled.

choices.text: Anterior division of middle cerebral artery
Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery
Posterior division of middle cerebral artery

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

 

The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.

 

The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum. Once inside, it divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery ascends vertically to supply the dura and the calvaria. Importantly, this artery courses in close proximity to the pterion. A blow to the pterion can fracture the thin bone here and rupture this artery, leading to an epidural hematoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

option A. Anterior division of middle cerebral artery: This artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes of the brain. After the middle cerebral artery (MCA) exits the lateral sulcus, it bifurcates into its anterior and posterior divisions. However, the MCA and its divisions run deep within the brain, within the depths of the lateral sulcus and over the insular cortex. While they are critical for brain function, they don't have a direct relationship to the pterion on the external surface of the skull.

 

Option C. Posterior division of middle cerebral artery: Similar to the anterior division, the posterior division of the middle cerebral artery runs deep within the brain and does not have a direct relationship to the pterion.

 

Option D. Stem of middle meningeal artery: The stem of the middle meningeal artery is the segment between its origin (from the maxillary artery) and its bifurcation into anterior and posterior divisions. As it enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum, the stem is somewhat close to the pterion but it's the anterior division that actually courses near the pterion on the inner surface of the skull.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone

questions.text: A young male weighing 46 kg was treated with a drug. It has a Vd of 6 L/kg and clearance of 4.6 L/hour. What is the approximate half-life of this drug? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 hours

 

Explanation: 


The half-life can be calculated using the formula:

 
t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance

 

  • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L
  • Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours


Educational Objective: 


The formula for calculating half-life (t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance) and remember to account for total Vd when given in L/kg by multiplying with body weight.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

D. Mitochondrial - 1. LHON (Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy):

LHON is caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA affecting the optic nerve and leading to vision loss.

 

A. AD (Autosomal Dominant) - 2. Myotonic Dystrophy:

Myotonic Dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by muscle wasting and myotonia, caused by an expanded repeat sequence in the DMPK gene.

 

B. AR (Autosomal recessive) 3. Cystic Fibrosis:

Cystic Fibrosis is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.

 

C. XR (X-Linked Recessive) 4. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy:

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the DMD gene, leading to progressive muscle degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different genetic disorders are inherited through various modes of inheritance: autosomal dominant (e.g., Myotonic Dystrophy), autosomal recessive (e.g., Cystic Fibrosis), X-linked recessive (e.g., Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy), and mitochondrial (e.g., LHON).

choices.text: 1 and 3 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
1 and 4 only

questions.text:
Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Ultrasonography
  2. MRI
  3. Angiography
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 2 only

 

Explanation:


Ultrasonography and MRI are key modalities used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

  • Ultrasonography (1): This is often the first imaging modality used to diagnose placenta accreta. It helps in visualizing the placental attachment and identifying abnormalities in placental implantation. Color Doppler ultrasonography is particularly useful to assess the blood flow and the vascularity of the placenta, which can indicate abnormal adherence.
  • MRI (2): MRI is used as a complementary imaging tool when ultrasonography results are inconclusive or to provide a more detailed view. It helps in evaluating the depth of placental invasion into the myometrium and can differentiate between placenta accreta, increta, and percreta.
  • Angiography (3): While angiography can provide information about blood vessels and may be used in some cases to evaluate blood flow abnormalities, it is not typically a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta. It may be used in specific scenarios or to plan surgical management, but it is not generally used for initial diagnosis.
  • X-ray (4): X-rays are not used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta due to their lack of sensitivity for soft tissue detail and the potential risk to the fetus. X-rays are not helpful in visualizing the placenta or its adherence to the uterine wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not commonly used for the initial diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

Option C: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta, and it excludes Ultrasonography, which is crucial for diagnosis.

 

Option D: Incorrect because X-ray is not used for diagnosing placenta accreta and does not contribute to the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Ultrasonography and MRI are the primary modalities used for diagnosing placenta accreta.

 

Ref: Page no 1982, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

 

Explanation:

 

The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.

 

Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.

 

Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.

 

Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:
